paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the V122I variant in the TTR gene associated with hereditary cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR-CM). It provides penetrance data and survival statistics for patients with this variant.

patients.demographics: Not specified in detail, but includes individuals with hereditary ATTR-CM.
patients.phenotype: Hereditary cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR-CM) associated with the V122I variant.

functional_data.summary: The V122I variant is associated with a more aggressive phenotype in hereditary cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in families, as it is a known pathogenic variant.
variants.population_frequency: Carried by 3.9% of individuals of African descent.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical association and population studies.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the increased mortality risk associated with the V122I variant.
key_quotes: The commonest hATTR‐CM is that associated with the V122I (p.V142I) TTR variant (V122I‐hATTR‐CM), carried by 3.9% of individuals of African descent.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper focused on the V122I variant in the TTR gene.
